Those are observed around the world and have significant impacts on marine ecosystems. The evaluated deep learning methods will be integrated for the task of marine heatwave prediction to overcome the limitations of spatiotemporal data and improve data-driven seasonal marine heatwave forecasts.

Motivation: Challenges in Spatiotemporal Data

Geophysical data have unique spatiotemporal properties that require specific considerations when used to build a machine learning-based prediction system. While machine learning approaches are commonly used for forecasting tasks, spatiotemporal forecasting has its own specificities that need to be accounted for when selecting a suitable approach. The selection process requires understanding the features of spatiotemporal data, which are high-dimensional, often limited in extent, and temporally correlated.

High dimensionality: Environmental data are indexed by up to three dimensions in space and one in time. A single climate event is usually caused by multiple factors. Observations or reanalysis datasets commonly contain tens to hundreds of variables that describe a single system. Domain knowledge can help select and reduce the number of variables to use as predictors in a machine learning algorithm. For example, in a recent study of marine heatwaves in the northwest Atlantic, the heatwave in 2012 was primarily driven by atmospheric forcing, and the heatwave in 2017 was driven by offshore oceanic forcing, indicating that the roles of different types of forcing vary from event to event. Without domain knowledge, determining the right combination of inputs from many variables is not straightforward. With the increasing demand for more interpretable machine learning models, the trend has been to introduce more variables as predictors into a model, leading to high dimensionality in the input.

Limited data: The training of a robust deep learning model requires a large amount of heterogeneous data to learn the entire possible range of behavior of the system. However, spatiotemporal data are often limited in extent. Temporally, data collection has evolved significantly with advances in physical equipment and technology, and the quality and extent of collected environmental data have increased greatly in the mid-to-late 20th century. Spatially, collection is limited to the physical environment on Earth, and the resolution might be rather low. For example, in the NCEP Global Ocean Data Assimilation System (GODAS) dataset (from 1980 to 2020), the spatial resolution of the dataset is 1 by 0.333 degrees, which may not be enough to capture localized climatological phenomena, and the temporal resolution may not be sufficient for training a robust deep learning model.

The temporal and spatial limitations of collecting data are unlikely to be mitigated by simply modifying the intervals. Transfer learning, including one-shot learning and zero-shot learning, from a similar learning task has proven its feasibility in the spatiotemporal space. However, finding a similar large dataset and/or an appropriate pre-trained model for transfer learning remains a problem. Temporal correlations.
